questions.question_text: Which two items are Cisco DevNet resources? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer C and E

Selected Answer: CE

Selected Answer: CE
It's C+E

The answer they give is correct. You can specify "requests.request()" with the HTTP Method inside (as they've done in this question with "PATCH"), or you can specify the HTTP method as the python attribute, e.g. requests.patch

So in this example, they have given the correct answer, however both of the below are completely valid:

response = requests.request("PATCH", url, headers= headers, data = payload ) print(response.text.encode('utf8'))

response = requests.patch(url, headers= headers, data = payload ) print(response.text.encode('utf8'))

request
header
payload

Buuut we can construct it using request when the method is inside of the response 
requests.request(method, url, **kwargs) 

https://2.python-requests.org/en/master/api/#requests.request

I think it should be:
response = requests.patch(url, headers=headers, data =payload)

comments.content: No, because you want to update the membership of a user, PATCH=Create

discussion.content: I'd think the first blank is "post", not "request".

'Authorization': 'Bearer' + my_token,

response = requests. ___________ (`PATCH`, url, headers= ___________, data = ____________ ) print(response.text.encode('utf8'))

discussion.content: To me, it's capacity.

Selected Answer: B
https://www.nextiva.com/blog/voip-problems.html

comments.content:
Jitter can cause audio drop-outs if the delay is high enough that the receiver considers the packets missing. Jitter buffers can help with this, but does not solve cases of very high jitter which can be caused by capacity issues. "If the jitter is so large that it causes packets to be received out of the range of this buffer, the out-of-range packets are discarded and dropouts are heard in the audio. For losses as small as one packet, the DSP interpolates what it thinks the audio should be and no problem is audible. When jitter exceeds what the DSP can do to make up for the missing packets, audio problems are heard."

Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/voice/voice-quality/18902-jitter-packet-voice.html
Capacity problems can also cause jitter due to queueing, but again... jitter shouldn't cause full drop-outs. That would typically be caused by dropped packets.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B should be the correct answer. Choppy voices and drop-outs are typically due to dropped packets, not jitter. Dropped packets are typically due to circuit capacity issues.

Jitter would cause something more like those robotic sounding voices, but not full drop-outs. Jitter means all the data is getting there, but in a less than timely fashion. It shouldn't cause full drop-outs.
why not capacity?

comments.content: the old question that has plagued every exam i took on the unified comms track: "do we assume qos on or off?"

discussion.content:
Simple delay and latency in the context both are the same.
Jitter is correct, if the jitter is higher , more posiblitily get lost packets

comments.content:
Yes. "The main effects of jitter on VoIP calls include dropped calls, missing words, and service disruptions."

https://www.liveagent.com/customer-support-glossary/jitter-voip/

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Jitter is right!

questions.question_text: While developing a real-time VoIP application on a Cisco Webex platform, users report that their voice gets chopped or parts of the conversation drop out. Which network constraint is impacting the application?

discussion.content: ?sortBy=lastactivity
HTTP GET /v1/rooms?sortBy=lastactivity
The answer given is correct https://developer.webex.com/docs/api/v1/rooms/list-rooms
I agree on : ?sortBy=lastactivity
?sortBy=created lastactivity refers to last room with new messages so it could load an old room

questions.question_text:
FILL BLANK -
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

Fill in the blank to complete the query parameter and value so that the result set is returned in reverse chronological order (most recent first) based on when messages were posted to those rooms.
HTTP GET /v1/rooms ________________

choices.D: Generating the logs causes the CPU on the network controller to spike, which causes delays in forwarding the voice IP packets.
choices.B: The speed and duplex settings in Cisco DNA Center are set incorrectly, which causes the transfer to be too slow.
choices.A: The script is written in a low-level programming language where there is no memory safety. This causes a buffer overflow and disruption on the network.
choices.C: The script is running in the Voice VLAN and causes delays and jitter in the subnet.

discussion.content: Answer is C

comments.content: Not by default. You have to turn on autoQOS on Cisco switches. And who knows - this is most likely in a DC in this scenario. This question is also sorta far fetched. There are almost never voice issues on a LAN but that's my .02
The voice traffic uses QoS so it should not be affected due to other traffic due prioritization. So I believe the answer is D.

discussion.content:
If speed and duplex settings are incorrect, the problem should appears all the time.

During office hours, users are using the IP phones, if the application is running on the voice LAN accidentally, it will impact the quality of the voice
I think the hint here is that controllers usually doens't forward traffic on data plane. So, any cpu spike woulnd't cause any issue on the packet forwarding. Based on that my answer would be C.

Selected Answer: C
Ans is C

Selected Answer: D
It is possible that the issue is caused by D. Generating the logs could cause the CPU on the network controller to spike, which could lead to delays in forwarding the voice IP packets. This could result in poor quality of phone calls during the time when the script is running.

However, it is also possible that the issue could be caused by other factors, such as network congestion or issues with the configuration of the voice VLAN or the speed and duplex settings. It would be useful to gather more information about the network and the script to determine the root cause of the problem.

comments.content: I don't think that would be it. The network controller isn't responsible for forwarding packets. It's responsible for making routing decisions. Packet forwarding is data plane while network controllers are control plane. Even if the data plane and control plane were on the same router, the data plane should be happening in the line card hardware under normal circumstances, not the CPU.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I'd go for C since it makes sense although I doubt any one would do that in the real world. The other choice D doesn;t seems to be very relevant since the network controller is supposed to impact the control plane not the data plane, thus the data plan should still forward without interruptions/drops.

Selected Answer: D
Delay & jitter are not on the 'subnet' level, which is a L3 thing. C is worded by someone who has no idea about how networks operate. It has to be D.

Selected Answer: D
I’m going with D on this one.
For me it's D.

Selected Answer: C
Should be C, it seems to be the more logical option

Selected Answer: C
speed would case problems always, DNA doesnt control traffic, so its clearly C
The Answer is C. TCP and UDP should be separated to prevent such issues and is best practice to do so. You can bet your life savings the answer is C. lol

Selected Answer: B
Answer is C.

Answer is C, it says the script is running in Voice Vlan it says in clear that script is running in Voice Vlan and the same subnet, and not Data Vlan, so if script is running in Voice Vlan, even if there is QoS, it could cause jitter and drop backets depends on traffic.
Answer is C. DNA is just the control plane, and does not have anything with the dataplane.

answer is 'C'. DNAC is a controller, control plane only. Not responsible for forwarding traffic. If DNAC running impacts voice, which is normally isolated in its own VVLAN, then DNAC must be in the VVLAN

comments.content: Well, they don't give us any details about the VLAN configurations so we must asume the they are configured following the best practices. That is, not mixing voice and data VLANS. If that's the case, then C is not correct. On the other hand, although the controller does not handle the data plane. Depending on the type of packet, it may require to go to the control plane for further processing and here is where D comes in. Again, if they don't say the VLANs are mixed, we must asume they're correctly configured.

discussion.content:
Definitely D, on our network we avoid running scripts during day time because it might caused to increase the usage of the resources which might affect the performance of the device where you are getting the logs. 

C is wrong, it is not advisable to mixed up management traffic to a voice traffic, id rather have different vlan for managing the devices.

comments.content: is'nt it correct that Network controller does not forward voice packets? so it does not effect voice trafic?

discussion.content: Should be D. It doesnt say that DNA is network controller. The network controller on the LAN are getting busy due to large data sending from DNA.

comments.content: It says "generating the logs" is causing CPU spikes so it's clearly about DNA C
so the answer must be C

discussion.content: Generating log bundles could create a CPU spike. Also DNAC may not handle data plane traffic but it does handle the control plane which could affect route lookups.

comments.content:
I would not agree on this since control plane decision is not made on the DNAC. The RLOC table is hold on Control plane node, which is most likely switch or router.
SO C is mostl likely the correct answer

Had to scroll down to find an explanation that makes sense on why its C and not D. 
I’ve worked with TMS and VCS for video and D would be true for those, however, as you pointed out, the Dataplane is separated from the Controlplane, so C makes sense now.

discussion.content:
It's a silly question but as a CCIE for 18 years, I would say C is correct. 
A - clearly incorrect
B- The enterprise port (the port you use to connect to the server on) on DNA runs at 10Gbit/Full duplex only. So its 10Gbit or nothing.
C - Most likely, because DNA centre runs at 10Gbit, it overloads the Voice VLAN.
D - Complete rubbish. The DNA Server doesnt forward ANY dataplane traffic at all.

I think is not D, because DNA its only a controller.
Is C because, if the trafic generate in voice vlan an dont have QoS, it cause delaly

comments.content: DNA does not forward Voice packets. It is just a controller.

discussion.content: answer is D

questions.question_text:
A company has written a script that creates a log bundle from the Cisco DNA Center every day. The script runs without error and the log bundles are produced.
However, when the script is run during business hours, people report poor voice quality of phone calls. What explains this behavior?
